body: Thanks for catching that. This was the result of adding Couch support. There may be another change required. Will confirm.

If you're thinking about the future Node.js images for openwhisk, you might want to compare compilation and execution time when using a [Node.js image](https://github.com/mhart/alpine-node) that bases from [Alpine linux](http://www.alpinelinux.org/). They are tiny in comparison to the official Node.js images which base from Debian. 
REPOSITORY           TAG                 IMAGE ID            CREATED             VIRTUAL SIZE
node                 4                   14c6b4a1f30b        19 hours ago        643.7 MB
mhart/alpine-node    4                   ff9852bfb8ce        22 hours ago        36.04 MB

Digging around more, it looks like the official Node.js images will soon support Alpine Linux out of the box
https://github.com/nodejs/docker-node/issues/46

for someone who wants to run `wsk activation poll` in a `tail` -like fashion, i think an exponential back-off would be of disadvantage. i think the right long-term solution would be to offer sth like a websockets or syslog i/f ?
yes, I agree websockets or syslog is better long term.

`wsk property set --auth xxx:yyy` for some `xxx:yyy` as the auth key does not make an API call. It just writes to the wsk property file. Are you saying that after you set the auth key to an appropriate value, a subsequent API call fails?

If so, 
1. are you using cloudant or couchdb and did you run the script `createImmortalDbs`?
2. are you using one of the built in keys or a new key?
3. if using a new key, did you add the key to the db using `wskadmin create user ...`?

Lastly, check that the API host points to your deployment with `wsk property get --apihost`.
merged.
Latest PG is 98.
Kafka test in Java failed in Travis. I suspect this has to do with the consumer group leader selection. Fixing.

The comment "moves from a streaming interface to a polling interface":  tell me more?    what are the consequences?

The following looks like an infinite loop that will chew up 100% of CPU even when queue is empty.   Correct?   By design?

```
   while (!disconnect) {
+                    Try { getMessages() } map { records =>
+                        val count = records.size
+                        records foreach { r =>
+                            val topic = r.topic
+                            val partition = r.partition
+                            val offset = r.offset
+                            val msg = r.value
+                            info(self, s"processing $topic[$partition][$offset ($count)]")
+                            val consumed = process(msg)
+                        }
+                    } match {
+                        case Failure(t) => error(self, s"while polling: $t")
+                        case _          =>
                     }
```

This is laying the ground work for a resource aware Kafka consumer with manual (explicit) offset management. We cannot do that with the streaming interface. The current change is "semantic preserving". The real change is coming next.
merged.

As a first shot, let's assume the user has [**homebrew**](http://brew.sh/) with [Caskroom](https://caskroom.github.io/) installed. That will greatly simplify the setup process. 

To install our prereqs, one can then issue:

```
brew cask install virtualbox
brew install https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Homebrew/homebrew-core/e010e91a6bb5ad6697fb158017b36f575bbe644f/Formula/docker.rb # install docker
brew install docker-machine
brew install ant
brew install ant-contrib

brew cask install java
brew install scala
brew install gradle

sudo pip install jsonschema
```

After that, create your machine using

```
docker-machine create -d virtualbox --virtualbox-memory 4096 --virtualbox-boot2docker-url=https://github.com/boot2docker/boot2docker/releases/download/v1.10.3/boot2docker.iso whisk
```

Run the script tweak script

```
tools/macos/tweak-dockermachine.sh
```

Restart your machine

```
docker-machine restart whisk
```

The interesting part will be handling the requirements compiling. Lambda currently punts on this and requires users to upload all the packages (compiled) as part of their code. The problem is if I'm a mac user and compile lxml, it won't run on lambda because it's Amazon Linux.  At the most basic level, having  whisk run a 'pip install' (maybe even create a virtualenv) of a requirements.txt to get/compile required actions for the user would be big. That's basically what cloud foundry does in it's python buildpack.
Use `update` to define new prameters. These _replace_ existing ones.
As I understand it, this will replace existing parameters with new ones, but not delete them.
PG 103
That's true, from the CLI, you can replace but not delete. If you made a direct API call, you could delete and replace the parameters.

I figure out what is wrong. After setting up the local development environment; I run `wsk property set --apihost` pointing to Vagrant. I forget to change the apihost back to openwhisk.ng.bluemix.net. Be better, you may add documentation mentioning the proper --apihost

```
sudo pip install --upgrade https://new-console.ng.bluemix.net/openwhisk/cli/download 
```

Do you know how to turn the logging on in whisk.js, I see it has a logger but I couldn't work out how to turn it on, I think that would be more useful as it is the call to whisk.invoke that is failing and it looks like the -v flag only enables logging for the initial call from the cli.

Thanks,

Iain

We don't install all these samples by default. You can create and install it yourself. 

The reason countdown isn't installed for example is that it is recursive and does not for simplicity specify the namespace for the action. So if it was installed as a sample but invoked by a different subject, that subject must have countdown in their namespace (assets) otherwise the invoke will fail with "not found".

If running on Bluemix, make sure the action you are invoking is using a fully qualified name including the namespace you are in when using Bluemix (e.g., `/duncan_dev/myAction`). From the CLI you can see your namespaces with `wsk namespace list` and you can change it with `wsk property set --namespace`

I tried it out and observed two things:
- it worked with my private namspace: `jerewern@de.ibm.com`
- it did not work with my shared namespace: `IBM Whisk_dev`

I've created the `countdown` action in my private namespace `jerewern@de.ibm.com`

```
wsk property set --namespace jerewern@de.ibm.com
wsk action create countdown ~/repos/openwhisk/catalog/samples/countdown.js
```

Then I invoked with the action with payload 10 and polled for activations:

```
wsk -v action invoke countdown --result --param n 10 && wsk activation poll
```

The result was:

```
{'apihost': 'openwhisk.ng.bluemix.net', 'namespace': 'jerewern@de.ibm.com', 'clibuild': '2016-03-14T11:48:47-05:00', 'apiversion': 'v1'}
========
REQUEST:
POST https://openwhisk.ng.bluemix.net/api/v1/namespaces/jerewern%40de.ibm.com/actions/countdown?blocking=false
Headers sent:
{
    "Authorization": "Basic ...",
    "Content-Type": "application/json"
}
Body sent:
{"n": 10}
--------
RESPONSE:
Got response with code 202
Body received:
{
  "activationId": "c58ff5e7be48484d8307aa05e1ba7385"
}
========
ok: invoked countdown with id c58ff5e7be48484d8307aa05e1ba7385
Hit Ctrl-C to exit.
Polling for logs
Activation: countdown (c58ff5e7be48484d8307aa05e1ba7385)
```

This is consistent with what I pointed out: the countdown example does not fully qualify the action name. Hence it will only work if you fully qualify the action in the code. Or as you did, create the action in the default namespace (which is assumed when you don't fully qualify an action name).
Since the first question was about running in Bluemix, you have to qualify the action name with the namespace you're running in or change your namespace as suggested by @jeremiaswerner.

Thanks, I've got this working by changing my namespace as described by @jeremiaswerner.  I had also tried to qualify the action name by doing this:

`name : '/iain.duncan@uk.ibm.com_iainduncani/countdown'`

but that didn't have any affect, @rabbah is that what you mean by qualifying the action name?

Cheers,
Iain
I will rebase to reflect changes in build scripts.
How do I use this? Is one top-level `gradle eclipse` enough?
Should be yes, `gradle eclipse` and then import as existing project in Eclipse.

There is a related bug in that the CLI itself is also not hosted at the API host.  There are some gaps in both the build and deployment scripts caused by a conflation of developer vs user role.  The first step is to make the dockerSkeleton tar ball available in the directory structure after a build and we should have this done soon.  The second step is to make sure both tar balls (CLI and docker skeleton) which may be delayed until our migration to a new build/deploy system is done.
cool stuff. thanks ;)

How recent is your checkout if you're using OpenWhisk (and not Bluemix). I fixed a bug related to this a few days ago in this [commit](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/commit/7b6acf4fc91ae36a1ed64198011c7d605f39a1fd).

`wsk -v package list`gives me: 
'clibuild': '2016-03-03T09:55:47-06:00'
'apiversion': 'v1'

As additional information: 
I downloaded the wsk binary from [https://new-console.ng.bluemix.net/openwhisk/cli](url) that points to a file named "openwhisk-0.1.0.tar". This file name hasn't changed since my last install so I guess either this file does not contain the latest version or the name has not changed.

@kolien, this order works for me:
1. create DB in Cloudant
2. create trigger on Cloudant changes feed per README.

I don't receive updates if I reverse the order and create the trigger before the DB exists.
Committed as 518bf71538d8f3815fdf90f4e01d90e2f3ad58b2.
Thanks for clearing that up for me. I did not try that. Maybe the readme should be updated with a information that the database has to be created first.
Yes.  Perhaps return an error if the trigger + feed cannot be setup successfully.

Hello, thank you for the pull request, including the tests. We have internally discussed the question of supporting promises, and in general agree that this is the direction we want to follow. Rather than supporting promises in legacy environments, however, we decided that we will first move forward with supporting more recent versions of Node.js. We will most likely use (at least part of) the code in this pull request then, which is why I'm leaving it open. Thanks again for the contribution!

I have noted a similar somewhat related behavior, that activation poll only registers information when "read" and "write" actions are invoked, but not when database content is changed or created using the Cloudant Dashboard (inside Bluemix)

Thank you for reporting this issue. The bug is actually not in the open source code base, but in bluemix-specific code. We’ll keep you updated on when a fix is rolled out so you can verify. Stay tuned!

I did a new test today.
1. Downloaded openwhisk CLI using pip.
2. Deleting old trigger.
3. Created a new trigger towards the same cloudant service that now already contains a testdb database. 
4. Starting activation poll
5. invoking read/write actions using CLI, receiving change related messages in activation poll as expected 
6. Manually creating docs and changing docs using cloudant dashboard, activation poll now does not reflect these changes (i.e. no updates in the changes logs)

My initial statement that "activation poll does not receive change information via the trigger" is still is valid.

Is the buildno now just the build number excluding any CI tags? Perhaps update the test which gets API info to check the build no matches a digits regex.

The buildno is the tag, as-is (a string). That's more consistent exposing the full tag otherwise we would concatenate later on which is error prone. Also in open and local it's `latest` which is not a number.
